{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} The '''Indian onion crisis''' of 2010 involved the dramatic rise in the cost of [[onion]]s across markets in India. The crisis was caused by errant rainfall in the onion producing regions which led to a shortage of onion production. The crisis caused political tension in the country and was described as "a grave concern" by then [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh]].<ref>{{cite news|last=AFP|title=En Inde, le prix de l'oignon peut faire perdre les élections|url=http://www.liberation.fr/monde/01012309510-en-inde-le-prix-de-l-oignon-peut-faire-perdre-les-elections|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=Libération|date=22 December 2010}}</ref>
==Background== Onions are considered an indispensable ingredient of most Indian cooking, providing the pungent foundation for a thousand different curries and other dishes. Onion prices have been an important political issue: they were regarded as the decisive factor in the 1998 state elections in [[Delhi]] and [[Rajasthan]], and were responsible for bringing down the central government in 1980.<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|last=Magnier|first=Mark|title=Indians in tears over skyrocketing onion prices|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/dec/27/world/la-fg-1227-india-onions-20101227|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=27 December 2010}}</ref> India is the second largest onion producer in the world, after China.<ref name="hindued">{{cite news|title=The political price of onions|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/editorial/article977100.ece|access-date=3 January 2011|newspaper=The Hindu (Editorial)|date=25 December 2010}}</ref>
Forty-five percent of the onion produce in India comes from the states of [[Maharashtra]] and [[Karnataka]]. In November 2010, unseasonal and excessive rainfall in onion-producing regions such as [[Nashik]] in [[Maharashtra]] delayed the arrival of onions in markets.<ref name="livemint">{{cite news|last=Mishra|first=Asit Ranjan|title=Skyrocketing onion prices add to government’s troubles|url=http://www.livemint.com/2010/12/21103634/Skyrocketing-onion-prices-add.html|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=LiveMint|date=21 December 2010}}</ref> In December, when fresh crop usually begins to arrive, onion shipments were reduced from 2000-3000 tons a day to 700-800 tons a day in New Delhi markets,<ref name="ft">{{cite news|last=Kazmin|first=Amy|title=India: politics of onions|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2010/12/21/india-politics-of-onions/|accessdate=9 January 2011|newspaper=The Financial Times|date=21 December 2010}}</ref> raising the price of onion from {{INRConvert|35|nolink=yes}} to {{INRConvert|88|nolink=yes}} per kg in the period of one week.<ref>{{cite news|title=Indian onions crisis: Custom duty slashed to zero|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12057398|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=BBC World|date=22 December 2010}}</ref> The price on some online portals was significantly lower, about 30-40/kg.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
==Aftermath== Wary of historical precedent, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and his government responded forcefully by banning onion exports, lowering import taxes and by getting in shipments of onions from neighbouring Pakistan.<ref name="dawn">{{cite news|title=Onions, coconuts and the politics of taste in S.Asia|url=http://www.dawn.com/2010/12/24/onions-coconuts-and-the-politics-of-taste-in-s-asia.html|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=The Dawn|date=24 December 2010}}</ref> In late December, following government restrictions on exports, wholesale onion prices went down to {{INRConvert|50|nolink=yes}} per kg in metropolitan markets.<ref name="hindocool">{{cite news|last=Mehdudia|first=Sujay|title=Onion starts to cool as tomato soars|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Economy/article977269.ece|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=The Hindu|date=25 December 2010}}</ref>
Along with errant rainfall, hoarding, official incompetence and price-ramping by traders have also been blamed for the crisis.<ref name="dawn"/> The [[Times of India]], in a [[back-of-the-envelope calculation]] alleged<ref name="latimes"/> that wholesale retailers and speculative traders in [[New Delhi]] charged a markup of over 135%, taking in profits of over {{INRConvert|1000000|nolink=yes}} a day.<ref name="TOIrobbery">{{cite news|last=Varma|first=Subodh|title=The great onion robbery: 135% mark-up from mandi to retail|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-12-23/india/28214746_1_onion-trade-wholesale-traders-delhi-s-azadpur|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=The Times of India|date=23 December 2010}}</ref> The opposition [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] blamed the crisis on policy decision on exports and imports.<ref name="livemint"/> Responding to a call from the opposition, 20,000 people demonstrated on the streets of New Delhi to protest the price rise and corruption in the government. The protesters included women and children wearing garlands of onions to symbolize inflation in the prices of basic commodities.<ref name="humanite">{{cite news|title=La crise de l'oignon en Inde|url=http://humanite.fr/27_12_2010-la-crise-de-loignon-en-inde-460875|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=L'Humanité|date=27 December 2010}}</ref>
In 2015 the retail prices of onions shot up again to INR 80/kg in Delhi.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-08-17/news/65526025_1_onion-rate-stored-onions-onion-prices |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305143758/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-08-17/news/65526025_1_onion-rate-stored-onions-onion-prices |archive-date=5 March 2016 |date=17 August 2015 |title=Onion prices go through the roof, retail at Rs 80/kg in Delhi |work=The Economic Times |access-date=27 September 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> While in Pakistan onions were retailing for PKR 40-50/kg.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.geo.tv/article-196090-Onion-prices-shoot-up-after-IndiaBangladesh-place-import-orders |title=Onion prices shoot up after India, Bangladesh place import orders |date=2 September 2015 |agency=AFP}}</ref> So the federal government decided to import onions from Pakistan.<ref name="forbes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2015/06/28/the-entirely-bizarre-market-for-onions-in-india/ |title=The Entirely Bizarre Market For Onions In India |last=Worstall |first=Tim |website=Forbes (blog) |date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
It was then suggested that there should be free trade in onions all year round.<ref name="forbes" />
==See also== *[[2010 United States tomato shortage]]

'''Al-Saadi Muammar Gaddafi''' ({{lang-ar|الساعدي معمر القذافي}}; born 25 May 1973), is the third son of former Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]]. He is a [[Libya]]n former [[association football]] player. In 2011, he was the commander of Libya's Special Forces and was involved in the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/regime-fears-army-revolt-20110309-1bnw9.html|title=Regime fears army revolt|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=10 March 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011|last=McElroy|first=Damien|location=London}}</ref> An [[Interpol notice]] was issued against him in 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/03/04/140202.html|title=Interpol issues global alert on Gaddafi & 15 others| work=Al Arabiya News|date=4 March 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref> On 5 March 2014, he was arrested in Niger and extradited to Libya, where he faces murder charges.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/06/us-libya-niger-gaddafi-idUSBREA2507220140306|title=Niger extradites Gaddafi's son Saadi to Tripoli, Libya says| work=Reuters|date=6 March 2014|accessdate=6 March 2014}}</ref> In August 2015, video surfaced allegedly showing Gaddafi being tortured.<ref name="guardian4815">{{cite news|last1=Stephen|first1=Chris|title=Saadi Gaddafi abuse video condemned by lawyers and rights groups|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/04/saadi-gaddafi-abuse-video-condemned-libya-al-hadba-tripoli|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=4 August 2014}}</ref>
== Football career == Gaddafi is known for his involvement in Libyan football. On 6 June 2000, the BBC reported that Gaddafi had signed with Maltese champions [[Birkirkara F.C.]] and would play for them in the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/in_depth/2000/champions_league/779758.stm|title=Gaddafi in Champions League|work=BBC News|date=6 June 2000}}</ref> The move failed to materialize.
Libyan football was arranged to favor Gaddafi. One law forbade announcing the name of any football player with the exception of Gaddafi. Only numbers of other players were announced. Referees favored Gaddafi's club and security forces were used to silence protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/06/05/151899.html|title=Benghazi soccer exemplifies the battle between Arab autocrats and their detractors|work=Al Arabiya|date=5 June 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011|last=Dorsey|first=James M.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/23/muammar-gaddafi-madness|title=Muammar Gaddafi: method in his 'madness'|work=The Guardian|date=23 February 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011|last=Whitaker|first=Brian|location=London}}</ref>
He signed for [[Italy|Italian]] [[Serie A]] team [[Perugia Calcio|Perugia]] in 2003, employing [[Diego Maradona]] as his technical consultant and Canadian sprinter [[Ben Johnson (sprinter)|Ben Johnson]] as his personal trainer.<ref name= BothroydGaddafi>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/duncanwhite/8855320/Jay-Bothroyd-puts-good-times-with-playboy-Saadi-Gaddafi-son-of-dead-Libya-tyrant-Colonel-Gaddafi-behind-him.html|work=The National Post| first=Duncan|last=White|title=Jay Bothroyd puts good times with playboy Saadi Gaddafi, son of dead Libya tyrant Colonel Gaddafi, behind him|date=29 October 2011|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> He made only one substitute appearance before failing a drug test.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesetpieces.com/features/football-gaddafi-family/|title=Football and the Gaddafi Family|author=Greg Lea|work=The Set Pieces|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> An article in ''[[la Repubblica]]'' said that "Even at twice his current speed he would still be twice as slow as slow itself."<ref>{{cite book|last=Shaw|first=Phil|title=The Book of Football Quotations|year=2008|publisher=Ebury Press|isbn=9780091923334|pages=32}}</ref>
He was also captain of the [[Libya national football team]], captain of his home club in Tripoli, and president of the [[Libyan Football Federation]].<ref name="natpost">{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/10/29/the-ontario-man-who-helped-muammar-gaddafis-son-flee-libya/|title=The Ontario man who helped Muammar Gaddafi's son flee Libya| work=The National Post|date=29 October 2011|accessdate=29 October 2011|last=Bell|first=Stewart|location=Toronto}}</ref>
Gaddafi joined [[UEFA Champions League]] qualifiers [[Udinese Calcio]] in 2005–06, playing only 10 minutes in an end-of-season league match against [[Cagliari Calcio]].
He joined [[U.C. Sampdoria]] during season 2006–07, without playing a single match.

== Business activities == In 2006, Al-Saadi Gaddafi and the Jamahiriya government launched a project to create a semi-autonomous city similar to [[Hong Kong]] in Libya, stretching 40 km between [[Tripoli]] and the [[Tunisia]]n border.<!-- Zawiya District? --> The proposed new city would become a high tech, banking, medical and educational center not requiring [[Visa (document)|visas]] to enter. The city would have its own international airport and a major seaport. Gaddafi promised religious tolerance with both "synagogues and churches" and no discrimination in this new metropolis. The new city would have "Western-style" business laws that Saadi thought European and American companies would find welcoming and familiar.<ref name="independent">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/alsaadi-gaddafi-libya-calling-418208.html|title=Al-Saadi Gaddafi: Libya calling|work=The Independent|date=1 October 2006|accessdate=15 October 2011| last=Owen|first=David}}</ref>
Gaddafi used to take great interest in the affairs of many of Libya's other business interests like [[Tamoil]], the oil refining and marketing company owned by the Libyan government, before the overthrow of the regime.<ref name=independent/>
=== Italian lawsuit === In July 2010, Gaddafi was ordered by an Italian court to pay €392,000 to a luxurious [[Liguria]]n hotel for an unpaid bill dating back to a month-long stay in the summer of 2007.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/10601275.stm|title=Italian court tells Gaddafi son to pay huge hotel bill| work=BBC World News|date=10 July 2010|accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref>
== Personal life == Gaddafi is married to the daughter of al-Khweildi al-Hmeidi, a [[Armed Forces of the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya|Libyan military commander]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12531442|title=The Gaddafi family tree|work=BBC News|date=21 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="theatlanticwire" />
In 2009, a U.S. diplomatic cable called Gaddafi "the black sheep" of Muammar Gaddafi's family. It mentioned scuffles with European police, "abuse of drugs and alcohol, excessive partying" and "profligate affairs with women and men".<ref name=Tel20110929>{{cite news|last=Farmer|first=Ben |date=29 September 2011|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8798089/Libya-Gaddafi-mouthpiece-caught-fleeing-dressed-as-a-woman.html|title=Libya: Gaddafi mouthpiece caught 'fleeing dressed as a woman'|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=1 October 2011}}</ref> Gaddafi's bisexuality had partly prompted the arrangement of his marriage to the commander's daughter, the cable said.<ref name="theatlanticwire">{{cite news|work=The Atlantic Wire|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2011/09/times-kept-qaddafis-sons-bisexuality-quiet-governments-request/42597/|title=New York Times Kept Qaddafi's Son's Bisexuality Quiet|date=16 September 2011}}</ref>
== 2011 to current ==
=== Libyan civil war === On 15 March 2011, there were unconfirmed reports that a [[Libyan Air Force (1951–2011)|pilot]] by the name of Muhammad Mokhtar Osman had [[Suicide attack|flown his jet into]] the Gaddafi stronghold of [[Bab al-Azizia]] in Tripoli damaging it and injuring him and his brother [[Khamis Gaddafi|Khamis]].
Speaking to BBC Panorama, a former Jamahiriya soldier claimed that Gaddafi had personally ordered to shoot unarmed protesters in Benghazi when visiting the city's army barracks at the beginning of the uprising. Gaddafi confirmed that he had been at the barracks but denied giving orders to fire on protesters.<ref name="bbcpanorama">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12789740|title=Saadi Gaddafi 'gave order to shoot' in Benghazi revolt|work=BBC| date=21 March 2011|accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref>
Gaddafi was reportedly the driving force behind a change in fighting tactics of the [[Armed Forces of the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya|government's forces]]. Instead of using heavy infantry, tanks and armored cars – which could easily be distinguished from the Free Libyan Army and then destroyed by allied fighter jets – the fight against the rebels was pursued with small, fast and versatile units.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.oe24.at/welt/libyen/Gaddafi-trickst-Rebellen-aus/21629016|title=Gaddafi trickst Rebellen aus|trans-title=Gaddafi tricks with rebels|work=OE24|date=30 March 2011| accessdate=15 October 2011|last=Wendl|first=Karl|language=German}}</ref>
The rebels claimed that they captured him during the [[Battle of Tripoli (2011)|Battle of Tripoli]], on 21 August, but later the claim turned out to be false.
On 24 August, Gaddafi contacted [[CNN]], stating that he had the authority to negotiate on behalf of loyalist forces, and wished to discuss a ceasefire with U.S. and NATO authorities.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/08/24/libya.saadi.gadhafi/index.html|title=Gadhafi son offers to broker Libya cease-fire|work=CNN|date=24 August 2011|accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref> A week later he contacted [[Al Arabiya]], stating his father was ready to step down, and called for dialogue with the [[National Transitional Council]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/31/164891.html|title=Saadi Qaddafi tells Al Arabiya his father is ready to relinquish power|date=31 August 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011|work=Al Arabiya|first=Mustapha|last=Ajbaili|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013185209/http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/31/164891.html|archive-date=13 October 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 5 September, Gaddafi said in an interview with CNN that an "aggressive" speech by his brother [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi|Saif al-Islam]] had led to the breakdown of talks between NTC forces and Gaddafi loyalists in [[Bani Walid]], and said he had not seen his father in two months. Gaddafi also claimed a position of neutrality in the conflict and offered to mediate.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/gaddafis-son-blames-brother-over-speech-20110905-1jtgp.html| title=Gaddafi's son blames brother over speech | work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=5 September 2011|agency=Agence France-Presse|accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref>
On 11 September, Gaddafi fled to [[Niger]] and was allowed entrance on humanitarian grounds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/09/2011911185616845334.html|title=Gaddafi son found as NTC rallies forces|work=Al Jazeera|date=11 September 2011|accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="natpost2">{{cite news| url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/10/31/government-urged-to-proble-gaddafi-sons-bodyguard-who-is-based-in-canada/| title=Probe urged into how Ontario-based bodyguard helped Gaddafi's son flee from Libya|work=The National Post|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=31 October 2011|last=McMahon|first=Tamsin|location=Toronto}}</ref> According to the government of Niger, they plan to detain Gaddafi while determining what to do with him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-sep-12-2011-2253|work=Al Jazeera|accessdate=15 October 2011|date=12 September 2011|title=Mon, 12 Sep 2011|agency=Reuters}}</ref> Gaddafi had also been trying to assemble a team to transport him to [[Barbados]] or [[Presidency of Hugo Chávez|Venezuela]].<ref name="natpost3">{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/10/31/ontario-man-offered-contractors-1000-a-day-to-transport-gaddafis-son/|title=Ontario man offered contractors $1,000 a day to transport Gaddafi's son|work=The National Post|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=31 October 2011|last=Bell|first=Stewart|location=Toronto}}</ref>
On 29 September, an Interpol [[red notice]] was issued for Gaddafi. [[Brigi Rafini]], the prime minister of Niger said he would not allow Gaddafi to be extradited.<ref name = Tel20110929/>
On 11 November, Niger's President [[Mahamadou Issoufou]] said his government had decided to grant Gaddafi asylum "on humanitarian grounds".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/11/saadi-gaddafi-asylum-niger|work=The Guardian|date=11 November 2011|title=Niger grants asylum to Saadi Gaddafi|first=David|last=Smith}}</ref>
On 7 December, the Mexican interior secretary said that Mexican intelligence agents broke up a smuggling ring attempting to bring Gaddafi into Mexico under a false name.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-16075043|title=Mexico 'stops entry' of Libya's Saadi Gaddafi|date=7 December 2011|accessdate=19 January 2012|work=BBC}}</ref>
=== Extradition and torture allegations === On 5 March 2014, Libya announced that Gaddafi had been extradited by Niger and was in Tripoli.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2014/03/05/world/africa/05reuters-libya-niger-gaddafi.html|date=5 March 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014|work=New York Times|title=Niger Extradites Gaddafi's Son Saadi: Libyan Government}}</ref> His lawyer, [[Nick Kaufman]], protested the move stating "extradition suggests that this was a legal process where Saadi Gadhafi was accorded a lawyer, a court hearing, and…it's not even clear to me that that even took place".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amanpour.blogs.cnn.com/2014/03/06/gadhafi-son-improperly-extradited-to-libya-former-lawyer-says/|title=Gadhafi son improperly extradited to Libya, former lawyer says|work=cnn.com|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
In May 2015, Gaddafi appeared in a Tripoli court and was formally charged with unlawful imprisonment and murder for the 2005 killing of football player [[Bashir al-Riani]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Spencer|first1=Richard|title=Saadi Gaddafi extradited to Libya|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/10679580/Saadi-Gaddafi-extradited-to-Libya.html|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=6 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Saadi Gaddafi in court in Libya for start of murder trial |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/11595914/Saadi-Gaddafi-in-court-in-Libya-for-start-of-murder-trial.html|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=10 May 2015}}</ref>
In early August 2015, video surfaced that appeared to show a blindfolded Gaddafi being forced to listen to other men allegedly being tortured in the next room. Then the guards beat the man appearing to be Gaddafi on the feet as he screams, after asking him if preferred to be beaten on the feet or on his buttocks. "It does appear to be Saadi Gaddafi," one of his lawyers, [[Melinda Taylor]], told [[Russia Today|RT]]. "He looks the same in sense [that] his head ... [had been] shaved which happened to him last year." No legal team appears to be present.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saadi Gaddafi torture video shows name guarantees 'maximum mistreatment' & no justice – lawyer to RT|url=https://www.rt.com/news/311494-saadi-gaddafi-torture-video/|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=[[Russia Today|RT]]|date=4 August 2015}}</ref>
International human rights groups and activists condemned the video, which appeared to take place at al-Hadba prison in Tripoli, and was first released by Arabic network Clear News.<ref name="guardian4815" />
"This is a shocking video that raises questions about conditions inside the prison," said [[Karim Ahmad Khan|Karim Khan]], a British attorney who represents Libya's former prime minister [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]], who is also at al-Hadba. "The international community needs to demand a full investigation."<ref name="guardian4815" />
An appeals court on 3 April 2018 cleared Saadi from the charge of murdering the footballer Bashir. He was however fined 500 [[Libyan dinar]]s and a [[Suspended sentence|suspended]] one-year prison term for drinking and possessing alcohol.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-security-saadi-gaddafi/libyan-court-clears-gaddafi-son-of-footballers-murder-idUSKCN1HA28Q|title=Libyan court clears Gaddafi son of footballer's murder|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>

Dr '''Alexander Kennedy''' MD [[FRSE]] FSA (1764-1827) was a Scottish surgeon and antiquary.
==Life== He was born on 22 June 1764.
He qualified as a surgeon at [[Aberdeen University]] in 1787. He immediately received an appointment with the [[East India Company]] as an assistant surgeon, being promoted to full Surgeon in 1795. This role would have seen him serve in a supportive role to many battles in India in the late 18th and early 19th century. In 1808 he took a more sedate and stationery role as Superintending Surgeon with the [[Indian Medical Service]] in [[Madras]], which he continued until 1812.
His career from 1812 to 1819 is unclear but in 1819 he appears as a practicing physician in [[Edinburgh]]. In the same year Aberdeen University awarded him a belated doctorate (MD) and he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Thomas Charles Hope]], James Russell and Sir [[David Brewster]]. He was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]] in 1820.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
He died at home, 6 Albany Street in [[New Town, Edinburgh|Edinburgh’s Second New Town]] on 27 March 1827. He is buried in [[St Cuthbert's Church, Edinburgh|St Cuthberts Churchyard]] at the junction of [[Princes Street]] and Lothian Road.

{{marriage|Marina|1994}} |children = {{hlist|Alexander|Sonia|Anatoly}} }} '''Alexander Valterovich Litvinenko''' ({{lang-rus|link=no|Алекса́ндр Ва́льтерович Литвине́нко|p=ɐlʲɪˈksandr ˈvaltɨrəvʲɪtɕ lʲɪtvʲɪˈnʲɛnkə}}; 30 August 1962{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/alexander-litvinenko-425720.html |title=Alexander Litvinenko |last=Penketh |first=Anne |date=25 November 2006 |work=The Independent |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oG9Erp6p?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/alexander-litvinenko-425720.html |archivedate=16 March 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]){{cite [[WebCite]]) or 4 December 1962 by father's account{{cite web|url=http://www.chechenpress.org/events/2006/12/04/22.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119003435/http://www.chechenpress.org/events/2006/12/04/22.shtml|title=CHECHENPRESS|archivedate=19 January 2012|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}} – 23 November 2006) was a British naturalised Russian [[defector]] and former officer of the Russian [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] secret service who specialised in tackling [[organised crime]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20715187 Litvinenko death: Russian spy 'was working for MI6'] – BBC News, 13 December 2012 According to US diplomats, Litvinenko coined the phrase [[Mafia state]].{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/04/spain-issues-arrest-warrants-for-russian-officials-close-to-putin | date = 5 November 2015 | access-date = 27 April 2016 | first1 = Alec | last1 = Luhn | first2 = Luke | last2 = Harding | authorlink2 = Luke Harding | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | location = London | title = Spain issues arrest warrants for Russian officials close to Putin}} In November 1998, Litvinenko and several other FSB officers publicly accused their superiors of ordering the assassination of the Russian tycoon and oligarch [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]]. Litvinenko was arrested the following March on charges of exceeding the authority of his position. He was acquitted in November 1999 but re-arrested before the charges were again dismissed in 2000. He fled with his family to London and was granted [[political asylum|asylum]] in the United Kingdom, where he worked as a journalist, writer and consultant for the British intelligence services. During his time in London, Litvinenko wrote two books, ''[[Blowing Up Russia: Terror from Within]]'' and ''[[Lubyanka Criminal Group]]'', wherein he accused the [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation|Russian secret services]] of staging the [[Russian apartment bombings]] and other terrorism acts in an effort to bring [[Vladimir Putin]] to power. He also accused Putin of ordering the [[Assassination of Anna Politkovskaya|murder in October 2006]] of the Russian journalist [[Anna Politkovskaya]]. On 1 November 2006, Litvinenko [[Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko|suddenly fell ill and was hospitalised]] in what was established as a case of poisoning by radioactive [[Polonium|polonium-210]]; he died from the poisoning on 23 November. He became the first known victim of lethal polonium 210-induced acute radiation syndrome.[[Guinness World Records]]: [http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/first-murder-by-radiation First murder by radiation]:
''On 23 November 2006, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Litvinenko, a retired member of the Russian security services (FSB), died from radiation poisoning in London, UK, becoming the first known victim of lethal Polonium 210-induced acute radiation syndrome.'' The events leading up to this are a matter of controversy, spawning numerous [[Alexander Litvinenko assassination theories|theories relating to his poisoning and death]]. A British murder investigation pointed to [[Andrey Lugovoy]], a former member of Russia's [[Federal Protective Service (Russia)|Federal Protective Service]], as the prime suspect. The United Kingdom demanded that Lugovoy be extradited, which is against the [[Constitution of Russia]], which directly prohibits[http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-03.htm Chapter 2. Rights and Freedoms of Man And Citizen | The Constitution of the Russian Federation]. Constitution.ru. Retrieved on 12 August 2013. extradition of Russian citizens. Russia denied the extradition, leading to the cooling of [[Russia–United Kingdom relations|relations between Russia and the United Kingdom]]. After Litvinenko's death, Marina Litvinenko, aided by biologist [[Alexander Goldfarb (biologist)|Alexander Goldfarb]], pursued a vigorous campaign through the [[Litvinenko Justice Foundation]]. In October 2011, she won the right for an [[inquest]] into her husband's death to be conducted by a [[coroner]] in London; the inquest was repeatedly set back by issues relating to examinable evidence. A [[public inquiry]] began on 27 January 2015,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2015/jan/27/alexander-litvinenko-public-enquiry-crown-court-murder-russia-polonium-poisoning|title=Alexander Litvinenko murder inquiry opens in high court|date=27 January 2015|work=The Guardian|accessdate=27 January 2015}} and concluded in January 2016 that Litvinenko's murder was an [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] operation that was probably personally approved by [[Vladimir Putin]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-35370819|title=President Putin 'probably' approved Litvinenko murder|date=21 January 2016|work=BBC News|accessdate=21 January 2016}} ==Early life and career== Alexander Litvinenko was born in the Russian city of [[Voronezh]] in 1962.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1535094/Alexander-Litvinenko.html |title=Alexander Litvinenko |date=25 November 2006 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oGA0PtBS?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1535094/Alexander-Litvinenko.html |archivedate=16 March 2010 |df=dmy }}( at [[WebCite]]) After he graduated from a [[Nalchik]] secondary school in 1980, he was drafted into the [[Internal Troops]] of the [[Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs|Ministry of Internal Affairs]] as a Private. After a year of service, he matriculated in the Kirov Higher Command School in [[Vladikavkaz]]. In 1981, Litvinenko married Nataliya, an accountant, with whom he had a son, Alexander, and a daughter, Sonia. This marriage ended in divorce in 1994 and in the same year Litvinenko married Marina, a ballroom dancer and fitness instructor, with whom he had a son, Anatoly.Oxford Dictionary of National Biography After graduation in 1985, Litvinenko became a [[platoon]] commander in the [[Dzerzhinsky Division]] of the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Soviet Union)|Soviet Ministry of Internal Affairs]]. He was assigned to the 4th Company of 4th Regiment, where among his duties was the protection of valuable cargo while in transit.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-2470058,00.html |title=Alexander Litvinenko |date=25 November 2006 |work=The Times |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=London }}([https://www.webcitation.org/5oGAMZAM9?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article649185.ece Archived] at [[WebCite]]) In 1986, he became an [[informant]] when he was recruited by the MVD's KGB [[counterintelligence]] section and in 1988, he was officially transferred to the Third Chief Directorate of the KGB, [[Military counterintelligence of the Soviet Army|Military Counter Intelligence]]. Later that year, after studying for a year at the [[Novosibirsk]] Military Counter Intelligence School, he became an operational officer and served in KGB military counterintelligence until 1991.{{cite web|url=http://www.prima-news.ru/news/articles/2002/10/10/17299.html |script-title=ru:Офицер ФСБ дает показания |author=Александр Подрабинек |date=10 October 2002 |publisher=Агентство ПРИМА |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211142149/http://www.prima-news.ru/news/articles/2002/10/10/17299.html |archivedate=11 December 2008 }} ==Career in Russian security services== In 1991, Litvinenko was promoted to the Central Staff of the [[Federal Counterintelligence Service]], specialising in [[Counter-terrorism|counter-terrorist]] activities and infiltration of [[organized crime|organised crime]]. He was awarded the title of "MUR veteran" for operations conducted with the Moscow criminal investigation department, the MUR.{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=D.M.|title=Alexander Solzhenitsyn – A Century in His Life|year=1998|publisher=St. Martinj's Press|location=New York|page=583}} Litvinenko also saw active military service in many of the so-called "hot spots" of the former [[USSR]] and Russia."In Memoriam Aleksander Litvinenko." Dir. Jose De Putter. VPRO Backlight, 2007. Documentary.[http://topdocumentaryfilms.com/alexander-litvinenko/] During the [[First Chechen War]], Litvinenko planted several FSB agents in Chechnya. Although he was often called a "Russian spy" by western press, throughout his career he was not an '[[intelligence agent]]' and did not deal with secrets beyond information on operations against organised criminal groups.{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2006/12/10/europe/EU_GEN_Britain_Poisoned_Spy_Wife.php |title=Russian authorities likely behind Litvinenko's death, his wife says |date=10 December 2006 |work=International Herald Tribune |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212163921/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2006/12/10/europe/EU_GEN_Britain_Poisoned_Spy_Wife.php |archivedate=12 December 2008 }} () Litvinenko met [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]] in 1994 when he took part in investigations into an assassination attempt on the [[Business oligarch|oligarch]]. He later was responsible for the oligarch's security. Litvinenko's employment under Berezovsky and other security services created a conflict of interest, but such practice is usually tolerated by the [[Government of Russia|Russian state]]. In 1997, Litvinenko was promoted to the FSB Directorate of Analysis and Suppression of Criminal Groups, with the title of senior operational officer and deputy head of the Seventh Section.{{cite news|url=http://www.wps.ru/ru/pp/tv-review/2006/11/30.html |script-title=ru:Радиоактивные политтехнологии: смерть Литвиненко осложнила проведение саммита Россия-ЕС |last=Vinogradskaya |first=Natalya |date=30 November 2006 |publisher="What the Papers Say" Agency |accessdate=16 March 2010 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oGl9u3VN?url=http://www.wps.ru/ru/pp/tv-review/2006/11/30.html |archivedate=16 March 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]){{Cite news|last=Simes |first=Dimitri |author-link=Dimitri Simes |title=Litvinenko: Kremlin Conspiracy or Blofeld Set-Up? |publisher=[[The National Interest]] |date=12 June 2006 |url=http://www.nationalinterest.org/BlogSE.aspx?id=13150 |accessdate=16 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oGlPfuO5?url=http://www.nationalinterest.org/BlogSE.aspx?id=13150 |archivedate=16 March 2010 |df=dmy }}( at [[WebCite]]) ==Conflict with FSB leadership== During his work in the FSB Litvinenko discovered numerous connections between top brass of Russian law enforcement agencies and [[Russian mafia]] groups, such as [[Solntsevskaya bratva|Solntsevo gang]]. He wrote a memorandum about that to [[Boris Yeltsin]]. Berezovsky arranged a meeting for him with FSB director [[Mikhail Barsukov]] and Deputy Director of Internal affairs Ovchinnikov to discuss the corruption problems;''Death of a dissident'', page 39-41. however, this had no effect. Litvinenko gradually realized that the entire system was corrupted from the top to the bottom. He explained: "If your partner bilked you, or a creditor did not pay, or a supplier did not deliver - where did you turn to complain? ...When force became a commodity, there was always demand for it. "[[Racket (crime)|Roofs]]" appeared, people who sheltered and protected your business. First it was provided by the mob, then by police, and soon even our own guys realized what was what, and then the rivalry began among gangsters, cops, and the [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation|Agency]] for market share. As the police and the FSB became more competitive, they squeezed the gangs out of the market. However, in many cases competition gave way to cooperation, and the services became gangsters themselves." According to US diplomats, Litvinenko coined the phrase [[Mafia state]]. On 25 July 1998, Berezovsky introduced Litvinenko to [[Vladimir Putin]]. He said: "Go see Putin. Make yourself known. See what a great guy we have installed, with your help."''[[Death of a Dissident]]'', page 136 That was very same day when [[Vladimir Putin]] replaced [[Nikolay Kovalyov (politician)|Nikolay Kovalyov]] as [[Federal Security Service#Heads of the FSB|the Director of the Federal Security Service]], with help from Berezovsky Litvinenko reported to Putin on corruption in the FSB, but Putin was unimpressed. Litvinenko said to his wife after the meeting: "I could see in his eyes that he hated me." Litvinenko said later that he was doing an investigation of Uzbek drug barons who received protection from the FSB, and Putin tried to stall the investigation to save his reputation.{{cite news|last=Litvinenko|first=Alexander|title=Why I believe Putin wanted me dead...|work=Daily Mail|date=25 November 2006|url=http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk/news/article-418652/Why-I-believe-Putin-wanted-dead-.html|accessdate=16 December 2011}} On 13 November 1998, Berezovsky wrote an open letter to Putin in [[Kommersant]]. He accused senior officers of the Directorate of Analysis and Suppression of Criminal Groups Major-General Yevgeny Khokholkov, N. Stepanov, A. Kamyshnikov, N. Yenin of ordering his assassination.{{cite news|last=Berezovsky|first=Boris|author-link=Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|title=Березовский (signed 11 November 1998)|publisher=[[Kommersant]]|date=13 November 1998|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/208710|accessdate=16 December 2011|language=ru}} Four days later, on 17 November, Litvinenko and four other officers appeared together in a press conference at the Russian news agency [[Interfax]]. All officers worked for both FSB in the Directorate of Analysis and Suppression of Criminal Groups. They repeated the allegation made by Berezovsky.{{cite web|script-title=ru:Березовский и УРПО / дело Литвиненко |publisher=Агентура.Ру |date=27 November 2006 |url=http://www.agentura.ru/timeline/1998/urpo/ |accessdate=30 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208212745/http://www.agentura.ru/timeline/1998/urpo/ |archivedate=8 December 2006 |deadurl=yes |language=ru |df=dmy }} The officers also said they were ordered to kill [[Mikhail Trepashkin]] who was also present at the press conference, and to kidnap a brother of the businessman [[Umar Dzhabrailov]].{{cite web|script-title=ru:Березовский и УРПО / дело Литвиненко |publisher="Агентура.Ру" |date=27 November 2006 |url=http://www.agentura.ru/timeline/1998/urpo/ |accessdate=30 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208212745/http://www.agentura.ru/timeline/1998/urpo/ |archivedate=8 December 2006 |deadurl=yes |language=ru |df=dmy }} In 2007, [[Sergey Dorenko]] provided [[The Associated Press]] and ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' with a complete copy of an interview he conducted in April 1998 for [[Channel One (Russia)|ORT]], a television station, with Litvinenko and his fellow employees. The interview, of which only excerpts were shown in 1998, shows the FSB officers, who were disguised in masks or dark glasses, claim that their bosses had ordered them to kill, kidnap or frame prominent Russian politicians and business people. After holding the press conference, Litvinenko was dismissed from the FSB.{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080518/107675252.html|title=Russia ready to cooperate with Britain on Litvinenko case – FSB|date=18 May 2008|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=16 March 2009}} Later, in an interview with [[Yelena Tregubova]], Putin said that he personally ordered the dismissal of Litvinenko, stating, "I fired Litvinenko and disbanded his unit ...because FSB officers should not stage press conferences. This is not their job. And they should not make internal scandals public."[[Alexander Goldfarb (microbiologist)|Alex Goldfarb]] and Marina Litvinenko. ''[[Death of a Dissident|Death of a Dissident: The Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko and the Return of the KGB]]'', The Free Press (2007) {{ISBN|1-4165-5165-4}} Litvinenko also believed that Putin was behind his arrest. He said, "Putin had the power to decide whether to pass my file to the prosecutors or not. He always hated me. And there was a bonus for him: by throwing me to the wolves he distanced himself from Boris [Berezovsky] in the eyes of FSB's generals."''Death of a Dissident'', p. 160. ==Flight from Russia and asylum in the United Kingdom== In October 2000, in violation of an order not to leave Moscow, Litvinenko and his family travelled to Turkey, possibly via Ukraine.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/world/europe/03iht-spy.3760139.html?pagewanted=all |title=Alexander Litvinenko lived and died in world of violence and betrayal |last=Cowell |first=Alan |author2=Shane, Scott |author3=Myers, Steven Lee |author4=Klimenko, Viktor |date=3 November 2006 |work=International Herald Tribune |accessdate=6 April 2010 |location=London/Washington, D.C./Moscow }} ([https://www.webcitation.org/5onGr9lbO?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/world/europe/03iht-spy.3760139.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all Archived] at [[WebCite]]) While in Turkey, Litvinenko applied for asylum at the [[Diplomatic missions of the United States|United States Embassy]] in [[Ankara]], but his application was denied. With the help of [[Alexander Goldfarb (microbiologist and activist)|Alexander Goldfarb]], Litvinenko bought air tickets for the [[Istanbul]]-London-Moscow flight,{{cite news|url=http://www.rg.ru/Anons/arc_2002/0330/hit.shtm |script-title=ru:Александр Литвиненко: ярлык предателя не радует |last=Dmitriyeva |first=Olga |date=30 March 2002 |publisher=[[Rossiyskaya Gazeta]] |accessdate=6 April 2010 |location=London |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5onHZ5cMR?url=http://www.rg.ru/Anons/arc_2002/0330/hit.shtm |archivedate=6 April 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]) and asked for [[political asylum]] at [[Heathrow Airport]] during the transit stop on 1 November 2000.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/news/newsid_1331000/1331949.stm |title=Литвиненко получил убежище в Британии? |date=15 May 2001 |publisher=[[BBC Russian Service]] |accessdate=6 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5onHgLPDf?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/news/newsid_1331000/1331949.stm |archivedate=6 April 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]) Political asylum was granted on 14 May 2001,{{cite web|script-title=ru:Заявление Александра Литвиненко |publisher=[[lenta.ru]] |date=15 May 2006 |url=http://www.lenta.ru/world/2001/05/15/litvinenko/statement.htm |accessdate=24 November 2006 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050913232153/http://www.lenta.ru/world/2001/05/15/litvinenko/statement.htm |archivedate=13 September 2005 }} not because of his knowledge on intelligence matters, according to Litvinenko, but rather on humanitarian grounds. While in London he became a journalist for [[Chechenpress]] and an author. He also joined Berezovsky in campaigning against Putin's government.{{cite book|title=Putin, Russia's choice|last=Sakwa|first=Richard|authorlink=Richard Sakwa|year=2008|edition=2nd|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-40765-6|pages=158–159}} In October 2006, he became a naturalised [[British nationality law|British citizen]] with residence in Whitehaven.{{cite news|title=Litvinenko was told that he was marked for death|publisher=Times|date=22 November 2006|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,3-2465271,00.html|accessdate=24 November 2006|location=London|first1=Michael|last1=Evans|first2=Daniel|last2=McGrory|first3=Sarah|last3=Delaney}} In 2002, Litvinenko was convicted [[trial in absentia|''in absentia'']] in Russia and given a three-and-a-half-year jail sentence for charges of corruption.[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/nov/25/guardianobituaries.russia Alexander Litvinenko] [[The Guardian]] Retrieved on 5 April 2008{{cite web|last=Litvinenko|first=Alexander|title=Alexander Litvinenko|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1535094/Alexander-Litvinenko.html|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=28 July 2002}} According to Litvinenko's widow, Marina Litvinenko, her husband co-operated with the British MI6 and MI5, working as a consultant and helping the agencies to combat Russian organised crime in Europe.[http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/10/17/58864214.html Litvinenko worked for UK intelligence – News – Politics – The Voice of Russia: News, Breaking news, Politics, Economics, Business, Russia, International current events, Expert opinion, podcasts, Video] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225114332/http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/10/17/58864214.html |date=25 February 2012 }}. : (17 October 2011). Retrieved on 12 August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/litvinenko-british-intelligence-lugovoy-979/|title='My husband was a British paid agent' – Litvinenko widow|work=RT International|accessdate=10 May 2016}} During the public inquiry started in January 2015, it was confirmed that Litvinenko was recruited by MI6 to provide "useful information about senior Kremlin figures and their links with Russian organised crime", primarily related to Russian mafia activities in Spain. Shortly before his death Litvinenko tipped off Spanish authorities on several organised crime bosses with links to Spain. During a meeting in May 2006 he allegedly provided security officials with information on the locations, roles, and activities of several "Russian" mafia figures with ties to Spain, including [[Zakhar Kalashov|Zahkar Kalashov]], [[Izguilov]] and [[Tariel Oniani]].{{cite web|author=[[Giles Tremlett|Tremlett, Giles]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/223006|title=US embassy cables: Spain's investigations into the Russian mafia|work=The Guardian|date=1 December 2010|accessdate=12 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215145344/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/223006|archivedate=15 December 2010 |deadurl=no}} Litvinenko converted to Islam in Britain to show his solidarity with exiled Chechen leaders.{{cite news |title=Putin 'probably approved' Litvinenko killing: UK inquiry |author=Natalia Kolesnikova |url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/putin-probably-approved-litvinenko-killing-uk-inquiry/ar-BBovteM |publisher=[[MSN]] |date=21 January 2016}} Visitors to Litvinenko's deathbed included [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]] and Litvinenko's father, Walter, who flew in from Moscow. Litvinenko told his father he had converted to Islam. Mrs Litvinenko said his father commented about it: "It doesn't matter. At least you're not a communist."{{cite news |title=Marina Litvinenko recounts last words of dying husband |author=Luke Harding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/03/marina-alexander-litvinenko-last-words-inquiry |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=2 August 2015}} [[Mikhail Trepashkin]] said that in 2002 he had warned Litvinenko that an FSB unit was assigned to assassinate him.{{cite news|title=Ex-Spy Claims Litvinenko Was Targeted|work=Washington Post|date=1 December 2006|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/01/AR2006120100452.html|accessdate=1 December 2006|first=Vladimir|last=Isachenkov}} In spite of this, Litvinenko often travelled overseas with no security arrangements, and freely mingled with the [[Russians in the United Kingdom|Russian community in the United Kingdom]], and often received journalists at his home. ==Allegations== Litvinenko had published a number of allegations about the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]], most of which are related to conducting or sponsoring domestic and foreign terrorism. ===Support of terrorism worldwide by the KGB and FSB=== Litvinenko stated that "all the bloodiest terrorists of the world" were connected to FSB-KGB, including [[Ilich Ramírez Sánchez|Carlos "The Jackal" Ramírez]], [[Yassir Arafat]], [[Saddam Hussein]], [[Abdullah Öcalan]], [[Wadie Haddad]] of the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]], [[George Hawi]] who led the [[Communist Party of Lebanon]], [[Ezekias Papaioannou]] from Cyprus, [[Sean Garland]] from Ireland, and many others. He said that all of them were trained, funded, and provided with weapons, explosives and counterfeit documents to carry out terrorist attacks worldwide and that each act of terrorism made by these people was carried out according to the task and under the rigid control of the KGB of the [[USSR]].[http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/regions/london/2005/07/318875.html The originator of the acts of terrorism in London was standing near Tony Blair] Retrieved on 3 April 2008 Litvinenko said that "the center of global terrorism is not in Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan or the Chechen Republic. The terrorism infection creeps away worldwide from the cabinets of the Lubyanka Square and the Kremlin".{{cite web|title=The originator of the acts of terrorism in London was standing near Tony Blair|date=19 July 2005|url=http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/regions/london/2005/07/318875.html|accessdate=30 November 2006}}{{cite web|first=Alexander |last=Litvinenko |title=The KGBism, Terrorism and Gangsterism are Triplets |publisher=Chechen Press |date=23 March 2005 |url=http://www.chechenpress.info/english/news/2005/03/23/03.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070516021611/http://www.chechenpress.info/english/news/2005/03/23/03.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 May 2007 }} When asked in an interview who he thought the originator of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|2005 bombings in London]] was, Litvinenko responded saying, "You know, I have spoken about it earlier and I shall say now, that I know only one organization, which has made terrorism the main tool of solving of political problems. It is the Russian special services."{{cite news|url=http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/regions/london/2005/07/318875.html|title=The originator of the acts of terrorism in London was standing near Tony Blair |date=19 July 2005|work=Chechenpress Department of Interviews|accessdate=1 October 2014}} Litvinenko also commented on a new law that "Russia has the right to carry out preemptive strikes on militant bases abroad" and explained that these "preemptive strikes may involve anything except nuclear weapons." Litvinenko said, "You know who they mean when they say 'terrorist bases abroad'? They mean us, [[Akhmed Zakayev|Zakayev]] and [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris]] and me." He also said that "It was considered in [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation|our service]] that poison is an easier weapon than a pistol." He referred to [[Poison laboratory of the Soviet secret services|a secret laboratory in Moscow]] that still continues development of deadly poisons, according to him.[http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=1140 Litvinenko's Poisoning: Detailed Unfolding of Events] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081225184931/http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=1140 |date=25 December 2008 }} ===Armenian parliament shooting=== {{Main|1999 Armenian parliament shooting}} Litvinenko accused the Main Intelligence Directorate of the General-Staff of the [[Military of Russia|Russian armed forces]] of having organised the [[1999 Armenian parliament shooting]] that killed the [[Prime Minister of Armenia]], [[Vazgen Sargsyan]], and seven members of parliament, ostensibly to derail the [[Conflict resolution|peace process]] which would have resolved the [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] conflict, but he offered no evidence to support the accusation.{{Cite book |last=Monaghan |first=Dr Andrew |last2=Plater Zyberk |first2=Henry |title=The UK & Russia – A Troubled Relationship Part I |chapter=Misunderstanding Russia: Alexander Litvinenko |pages=9–12 |isbn=978-1-905962-15-0 |publisher=[[Conflict Studies Research Centre]] of the [[Defence Academy of the United Kingdom]] |publication-date=22 May 2007 |url=http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/arag/document-listings/russian/07%2817%29AM.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=16 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5cI8esWSU?url=http://www.da.mod.uk/colleges/arag/document-listings/russian/07(17)AM.pdf |archivedate=13 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }} ( at [[WebCite]]){{cite news|url=http://realazer.com/_3/index.html|script-title=ru:Список киллеров ФСБ|date=29 April 2005|publisher=Реальный Азербайджан|accessdate=16 February 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104110225/http://realazer.com/_3/index.html|archivedate=4 November 2005|language=ru}}{{cite news|url=http://www.azg.am/EN/2005050307 |title=Shooting of the Armenian Parliament was organized by Russian special services |date=3 May 2005 |publisher=AZG Daily |accessdate=6 April 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1270569339JOFECUAZJM?url=http://www.azg.am/EN/2005050307 |archivedate=6 April 2010 }} ( at Freezepage.com) The [[Diplomatic missions of Russia|Russian embassy]] in Armenia denied any such involvement, and described Litvinenko's accusation as an attempt to harm [[Armenia–Russia relations|relations between Armenia and Russia]] by people against the democratic reforms in Russia.{{cite news|title=Russian embassy denies special services' part in Armenian parliament shooting|date=12 May 2005|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]}} ===Russian apartment bombings=== {{Main|Russian apartment bombings}} Litvinenko wrote two books, ''[[Lubyanka Criminal Group]]'' and ''[[Blowing Up Russia: Terror from Within]]'' (in co-authorship with historian [[Yuri Felshtinsky]]), where he accused the [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation|Russian secret services]] of staging the [[Russian apartment bombings]] and other terrorism acts in an effort to bring [[Vladimir Putin]] to power.{{cite news|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/print/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/012/907jbmkm.asp |title=The Truth About Beslan |last=Satter |first=David |date=13 November 2006 |publisher=[[The Weekly Standard]] |accessdate=6 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5omYjLpcq?url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/print/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/012/907jbmkm.asp |archivedate=6 April 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]) ===Moscow theatre hostage crisis=== {{Main|Moscow theatre hostage crisis}} In a 2003 interview with the Australian [[SBS (Australian TV channel)|SBS TV]] network, and aired on ''[[Dateline (Australian TV program)|Dateline]]'', Litvinenko claimed that two of the Chechen terrorists involved in the 2002 [[Moscow theatre hostage crisis|Moscow theatre siege]]—whom he named "Abdul the Bloody" and "Abu Bakar"—were working for the FSB, and that the agency manipulated the rebels into staging the attack.{{cite web|last=Lazaredes |first=Nick |title=Terrorism takes front stage – Russia's theatre siege |publisher=[[Dateline (Australian TV program)|Dateline]] |date=4 June 2003 |url=http://news.sbs.com.au/dateline/russia__terrorism_takes_front_stage_130217 |accessdate=13 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121162852/http://news.sbs.com.au/dateline/russia__terrorism_takes_front_stage_130217 |archivedate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Litvinenko said, "[W]hen they tried to find [Abdul the Bloody and Abu Bakar] among the dead terrorists, they weren't there. The FSB got its agents out. So the FSB agents among Chechens organized the whole thing on FSB orders, and those agents were released." This echoed similar claims made by [[Mikhail Trepashkin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=13&issue_id=596&article_id=4407|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050109094437/http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=13&issue_id=596&article_id=4407|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 January 2005|title=Programs - The Jamestown Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}} The leading role of an [[FSB (Russia)|FSB]] agent, ''Khanpasha Terkibaev'' ("Abu Bakar"), was also described by [[Anna Politkovskaya]], [[Ivan Rybkin]] and [[Alexander Khinshtein]].{{cite web|url=http://jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?issue_id=570|title=North Caucasus Weekly - The Jamestown Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006113209/http://jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?issue_id=570|archivedate=6 October 2008|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=13&issue_id=574&article_id=4199|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040312170143/http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=13&issue_id=574&article_id=4199|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 March 2004|title=Programs - The Jamestown Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}}[http://eng.terror99.ru/publications/098.htm Russian Authorities Hedge Over Special Services Involvement In Moscow Theater Siege] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025042808/http://eng.terror99.ru/publications/098.htm |date=25 October 2007 }}, by [[Anna Politkovskaya]], ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', 5 May 2003{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Article/1342392.html|title=Corruption Watch: December 18, 2003|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=10 May 2016}} In the beginning of April 2003 Litvinenko gave "the Terkibaev file" to [[Sergei Yushenkov]] when he visited London, who in turn passed it to [[Anna Politkovskaya]]. A few days later Yushenkov was assassinated. Terkibaev was later killed in Chechnya. According to [[Ivan Rybkin]], a speaker of the [[Russian State Duma]], "The authorities failed to keep [the FSB agent] Terkibaev out of public view, and that is why he was killed. I know how angry people were, because they knew Terkibaev had authorization from presidential administration."[[Anna Politkovskaya]] ''[[A Russian Diary: A Journalist's Final Account of Life, Corruption, and Death in Putin's Russia]]'', Random House, New York, 2007, {{ISBN|978-1-4000-6682-7}}, page 56. ===Beslan school siege=== {{Main|Beslan school siege}} In September 2004, Alexander Litvinenko suggested that the Russian secret services must have been aware of the plot beforehand and probably have organised the attack themselves in order to [[Beslan school siege#Long-term effects|toughen laws on terrorism and expand the powers of law enforcement agencies]]. His conclusion was based on the fact that several Beslan hostage takers had been released from FSB custody just before the attack in Beslan. He said that they would only have been freed if they were of use to the FSB, and that even in the case that they were freed without being turned into FSB assets, they would be under a strict surveillance that would not have allowed them to carry out the Beslan attack unnoticed.[http://halldor2.blogspot.com/2004/09/litvinenko-on-beslan.html A. Litvinenko: "The identities of the terrorists prove 100% the participation of the FSB in the seizure of the school in Beslan"], [[Chechenpress]], 8 September 2004 Ella Kesayeva, co-chair of the group [[Voice of Beslan]], supported Litvinenko's argument in a November 2008 article in ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', noting the large number of hostage takers who were in government custody not long before attacking the school, and coming to the same conclusion.{{cite news|url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/data/2008/86/00.html |script-title=ru:Террористы-агенты – Неизвестные подробности бесланской трагедии |last=Kesayeva |first=Ella |date=20 November 2008 |publisher=Novaya Gazeta |accessdate=6 April 2010 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5omZuHJiK?url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/data/2008/86/00.html |archivedate=6 April 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]) ===Alleged Russia–al-Qaeda connection=== In a July 2005 interview with the Polish newspaper ''[[Rzeczpospolita (newspaper)|Rzeczpospolita]]'', Litvinenko alleged that [[Ayman al-Zawahiri]], a prominent leader of al-Qaeda, was trained for half a year by the FSB in [[Dagestan]] in 1997.{{cite web|last=Nyquist|first=J.R.|title=Kremlin Poison|publisher=Financial Sense Online|date=20 November 2006|url=http://www.financialsense.com/stormwatch/geo/pastanalysis/2006/1120.html|accessdate=21 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129203038/http://www.financialsense.com/stormwatch/geo/pastanalysis/2006/1120.html|archivedate=29 November 2006|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Litvinenko said that after this training, al-Zawahiri "was transferred to [[Afghanistan]], where he had never been before and where, following the recommendation of his Lubyanka chiefs, he at once ... penetrated the milieu of [[Osama bin Laden]] and soon became his assistant in [[Al Qaeda]]."{{cite web|last=Nyquist|first=J.R.|title=Is Al Qaeda a Kremlin Proxy?|date=13 August 2005|url=http://www.jrnyquist.com/nyquist_2005_0813.htm|accessdate=29 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061031111903/http://www.jrnyquist.com/nyquist_2005_0813.htm|archivedate=31 October 2006 |deadurl=no}} [[Konstantin Preobrazhenskiy]], a former KGB officer and writer, supported this claim and said that Litvinenko "was responsible for securing the secrecy of Al-Zawahiri's arrival in Russia; he was trained by FSB instructors in Dagestan, Northern Caucasus, in 1996–1997."[http://cicentre.com/Documents/russia_islam_not_separate.html Russia and Islam are not Separate: Why Russia backs Al-Qaeda] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219040336/http://cicentre.com/Documents/russia_islam_not_separate.html |date=19 December 2007}}, by Konstantin Preobrazhensky. He said: "At that time, Litvinenko was the Head of the Subdivision for Internationally Wanted Terrorists of the First Department of the Operative-Inquiry Directorate of the FSB Anti-Terrorist Department. He was ordered to undertake the delicate mission of securing Al-Zawahiri from unintentional disclosure by the Russian police. Though Al-Zawahiri had been brought to Russia by the FSB using a false passport, it was still possible for the police to learn about his arrival and report to Moscow for verification. Such a process could disclose Al-Zawahiri as an FSB collaborator. In order to prevent this, Litvinenko visited a group of highly placed police officers to notify them in advance." According to Sergei Ignatchenko, an FSB spokesman, al-Zawahiri was arrested by Russian authorities in Dagestan in December 1996 and released in May 1997.{{cite web|first=Khalil|last=Gebara|title=The End of Egyptian Islamic Jihad?|publisher=The Jamestown Foundation|date=10 February 2005|url=http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=411&issue_id=3228&article_id=2369243|accessdate=7 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061121012526/http://www.jamestown.org/publications_details.php?volume_id=411&issue_id=3228&article_id=2369243|archivedate=21 November 2006}} ===Assassination of Anna Politkovskaya=== {{Main|Anna Politkovskaya assassination}} Two weeks before his poisoning, Alexander Litvinenko accused [[Vladimir Putin]] of ordering the assassination of the Russian journalist [[Anna Politkovskaya]] and stated that a former presidential candidate, [[Irina Hakamada]], warned Politkovskaya about threats to her life coming from the Russian president. Litvinenko advised Politkovskaya to escape from Russia immediately. Hakamada denied her involvement in passing any specific threats, and said that she warned Politkovskaya only in general terms more than a year earlier.{{cite web|script-title=ru:Ирина Хакамада о партийном строительстве и экономической ситуации в России |publisher=Svoboda News |date=4 December 2006 |url=http://www.svobodanews.ru/Transcript/2006/12/04/20061204200017950.html |accessdate=7 December 2006 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930180758/http://www.svobodanews.ru/Transcript/2006/12/04/20061204200017950.html |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy }} It remains unclear if Litvinenko referred to an earlier statement made by [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]], who claimed that [[Boris Nemtsov]], a former [[Deputy Prime Minister of Russia]], received word from Hakamada that Putin threatened her and like-minded colleagues in person. According to Berezovsky, Putin stated that Hakamada and her colleagues "will take in the head immediately, literally, not figuratively" if they "open the mouth" about the [[Russian apartment bombings]].Live interview with Berezovsky by [[Evgenia Albats]], Radio [[Echo of Moscow]], 11 June 2006. [http://www.echo.msk.ru/interview/44072/ Transcript in Russian], [https://archive.is/20120908212552/http://www.online-translator.com/url/tran_url.asp?direction=re&autotranslate=on&transliterate=on&url=http://www.echo.msk.ru/interview/44072/ computer translation] . ===Allegations concerning Romano Prodi=== {{Main|Italian Mitrokhin Commission}} According to Litvinenko, the FSB deputy chief General [[Anatoly Trofimov]] said to him, "Don't go to Italy, there are many KGB agents among the politicians. Romano Prodi is our man there,"{{cite web|title=Gerard Battem, One-minute speeches on matters of political importance|publisher=European Parliament, Debates|date=3 April 2006|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+CRE+20060403+ITEM-008+DOC+XML+V0//EN&language=EN&query=INTERV&detail=1-060|accessdate=13 March 2008 }}{{cite web|title=Former FSB General, Wife Shot Dead in Moscow|publisher=Mosnews.com|date=11 April 2005|url=http://www.mosnews.com/news/2005/04/11/fsbhit.shtml|archive-url=https://archive.is/20061113085720/http://www.mosnews.com/news/2005/04/11/fsbhit.shtml|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 November 2006|accessdate=21 November 2006}} meaning [[Romano Prodi]], the Italian centre-left leader, former [[Prime Minister of Italy]] and former President of the [[European Commission]]. The conversation with Trofimov took place in 2000, after the Prodi-KGB scandal broke out in October 1999 due to information about Prodi provided by [[Vasili Mitrokhin]].''Death of a Dissident'', page 342 In April 2006, a British [[Member of the European Parliament]] for London, [[Gerard Batten]] of the [[United Kingdom Independence Party]] (UKIP), demanded an inquiry into the allegations. According to the [[Brussels]]-based newspaper ''The EU Reporter'' on 3 April 2006, "Another high-level source, a former KGB operative in London, has confirmed the story."{{cite web|last=Donnelly|first=Cillian|title=Prodi Accused of Being Former Soviet Agent|publisher=EU Reporter|date=3 April 2006|url=http://www.eureporter.co.uk/showarticle.php?newsid=2218|accessdate=21 November 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060524063146/http://www.eureporter.co.uk/showarticle.php?newsid=2218|archivedate=24 May 2006}} On 26 April 2006, Batten repeated his call for a parliamentary inquiry, revealing that "former senior members of the KGB are willing to testify in such an investigation, under the right conditions." He added, "It is not acceptable that this situation is unresolved, given the importance of Russia's relations with the European Union."{{cite web|last=Batten|first=Gerard|title=2006: Speech in the European Parliament: Romano Prodi|publisher=[[Gerard Batten]] MEP|date=26 April 2006|url=http://www.gerardbattenmep.co.uk/search.php?misc=search&subaction=showfull&id=1146224529&archive=&cnshow=news&start_from=&%5C%22to_date_day%5C%22=&TB=home5|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083202/http://www.gerardbattenmep.co.uk/search.php?misc=search&subaction=showfull&id=1146224529&archive=&cnshow=news&start_from=&%5C%22to_date_day%5C%22=&TB=home5|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 September 2007|accessdate=21 November 2006}} On 22 January 2007, the [[BBC]] and [[ITV News]] released documents and video footage from February 2006, in which Litvinenko repeated his statements about Prodi.{{cite news|title='Multiple attempts' on Litvinenko|publisher=BBC|date=22 January 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6285631.stm|accessdate=1 March 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208233040/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6285631.stm|archivedate=8 February 2007 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web|title=Litvinenko footage emerges |publisher=[[ITV News]] |date=22 January 2007 |url=http://www.itv.com/news/index_de20839cb1d32bc0891bbbd13c6a4c1e.html |accessdate=1 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929104844/http://www.itv.com/news/index_de20839cb1d32bc0891bbbd13c6a4c1e.html |archivedate=29 September 2007 }} ===Connections between FSB and mafia=== In his book ''[[Gang from Lubyanka]]'', Litvinenko alleged that [[Vladimir Putin]] during his time at the FSB was personally involved in [[Protection racket|protecting]] the drug trafficking from Afghanistan organised by [[Abdul Rashid Dostum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.compromat.ru/main/fsb/litvinenkolpgg4.htm |title=Хохольков и его команда|accessdate=19 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028171001/http://www.compromat.ru/main/fsb/litvinenkolpgg4.htm |archivedate=28 October 2011 }} In December 2003, Russian authorities confiscated over 4,000 copies of the book.{{cite web|title=Russian editor questioned over seizure of controversial book (BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union, text of report by Russian news agency Ekho Moskvy ) |publisher=Terror 99 |date=29 January 2004 |url=http://eng.terror99.ru/publications/133.htm |accessdate=23 December 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207044901/http://eng.terror99.ru/publications/133.htm |archivedate=7 December 2006 |deadurl=yes}} Shortly before his death, Alexander Litvinenko alleged that [[Vladimir Putin]] had cultivated a "good relationship" with [[Semion Mogilevich]] (head of the Russia mafia) since 1993 or 1994.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/11364900/Listen-Alexander-Litvinenkos-apparent-warning-before-his-death.html Listen: Alexander Litvinenko's apparent warning before his death] By Lyndsey Telford, Edward Malnick and Claire Newell, ''Telegraph'', 23 January 2015 ===Others=== In an article written by Litvinenko in July 2006, and published online on Zakayev's [[Chechenpress]] website, he claimed that [[Vladimir Putin]] is a [[paedophile]].{{cite web|last=Litvinenko|first=Alexander|title=The Kremlin Pedophile|publisher=[[Chechenpress]]|date=5 July 2006|url=http://www.chechenpress.co.uk/english/news/2006/07/05/01.shtml|accessdate=11 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211235729/http://www.chechenpress.co.uk/english/news/2006/07/05/01.shtml|archivedate=11 December 2008|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Litvinenko also claimed that [[Anatoly Trofimov]] and [[Artyom Borovik]] knew of the alleged paedophilia.{{cite web|last=Litvinenko |first=Alexander |script-title=ru:Кремлевский чикатило |publisher=[[Chechenpress]] |date=5 July 2006 |url=http://www.chechenpress.info/events/2006/07/05/03.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20061210041449/http://www.chechenpress.info/events/2006/07/05/03.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 December 2006 |language=ru }} Litvinenko made the allegation after Putin kissed a boy on his stomach while stopping to chat with some tourists during a walk in the Kremlin grounds on 28 June 2006. The incident was recalled in a [[webcast]] organised by the [[BBC]] and [[Yandex]], in which over 11,000 people asked Putin to explain the act, to which he responded, "He seemed very independent and serious... I wanted to cuddle him like a kitten and it came out in this gesture. He seemed so nice. ... There is nothing behind it."{{cite news|title=Putin recalls kissing boy's belly|publisher=BBC News|date=6 July 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5155448.stm|accessdate=11 November 2008}} According to Litvinenko, the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|2005 controversy]] over the publication in the [[Newspapers in Denmark|Danish newspaper]] ''[[Jyllands-Posten]]'' of editorial cartoons depicting the Islamic [[prophet]] [[Muhammad]] was orchestrated by the FSB to punish [[Denmark]] for its refusal to extradite [[Chechen Republic of Ichkeria|Chechen separatists]].{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2006/12/14/litvinenko/ |title=From Russia with lies |last=Mainville |first=Michael |date=14 December 2006 |publisher=[[Salon.com]] |accessdate=6 April 2010 |location=Moscow |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5omXP47Oa?url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2006/12/14/litvinenko/ |archivedate=6 April 2010 |df=dmy }} ( at [[WebCite]]) ==Poisoning and death== {{Main|Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko}} [[File:AlexanderLitvinenkoHospital.jpg|right|thumb|A bald Litvinenko at [[University College Hospital]]]] On 1 November 2006, Litvinenko suddenly fell ill. On 3 November, he was admitted to Barnet General Hospital in London.{{cite journal|url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(16)00144-6/abstract|title=Polonium-210 poisoning: a first-hand account|first1=Amit C|last1=Nathwani|first2=James F|last2=Down|first3=John|last3=Goldstone|first4=James|last4=Yassin|first5=Paul I|last5=Dargan|first6=Andres|last6=Virchis|first7=Nick|last7=Gent|first8=David|last8=Lloyd|first9=John D|last9=Harrison|date=10 September 2016|publisher=|journal=The Lancet|volume=388|issue=10049|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(16)00144-6}} He was then moved to [[University College Hospital]] for intensive care. His illness was later attributed to poisoning with [[radionuclide]] [[polonium-210]] after the [[Health Protection Agency]] found significant amounts of the rare and highly toxic element in his body.{{cite news|title=Litvinenko: A deadly trail of polonium|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-33678717|accessdate=21 January 2016|work=BBC|date=28 July 2015}} Litvinenko met with two former KGB agents early on the day he fell ill – [[Dmitry Kovtun]] and [[Andrei Lugovoy]]. Though both denied any wrongdoing, a leaked [[United States diplomatic cables leak|US diplomatic cable]] revealed that Kovtun had left polonium traces in the house and car he had used in [[Hamburg]].{{cite web|url=https://search.wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/06HAMBURG85_a.html|title=Full-text search|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2016}} The men also introduced Litvinenko to a tall, thin man of central Asian appearance called 'Vladislav Sokolenko' who Lugovoy said was a business partner. Lugovoy is also a former bodyguard of Russian ex-Acting Prime minister [[Yegor Gaidar]] (who also suffered from a mysterious illness in November 2006). Later, Litvinenko had lunch at [[Itsu]], a [[sushi]] restaurant in Piccadilly in London, with an Italian acquaintance and [[nuclear waste]] expert, [[Mario Scaramella]], to whom he made the allegations regarding Italy's Prime Minister [[Romano Prodi]].{{cite web|last=Batten|first=Gerard|title=Gerard Batten MEP – "60-second speech to the European Parliament "Romano Prodi" – Strasbourg|publisher=[[United Kingdom Independence Party]]|date=3 April 2006|url=http://www.ukip.org/ukip_news/gen12.php?t=1&id=2055|accessdate=21 November 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061013081221/http://www.ukip.org/ukip_news/gen12.php?t=1&id=2055|archivedate=13 October 2006}} Scaramella, attached to the [[Mitrokhin Commission#Mitrokhin Commission|Mitrokhin Commission]] investigating KGB penetration of Italian politics, claimed to have information on the [[Anna Politkovskaya assassination|assassination]] of [[Anna Politkovskaya]], 48, a journalist who was killed at her Moscow apartment building in October 2006. Marina Litvinenko, his widow, accused Moscow of orchestrating the murder. Though she believes the order did not come from Putin himself, she does believe it was done at the behest of the authorities, and announced that she will refuse to provide evidence to any Russian investigation out of fear that it would be misused or misrepresented.{{cite news|title=Dead spy's widow accuses Russian authorities|publisher=CNN|date=10 December 2006|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/12/10/russia.spy/index.html|accessdate=10 December 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061212004137/http://edition.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/12/10/russia.spy/index.html|archivedate=12 December 2006}} On a court hearing in London in 2015, a [[Scotland Yard]] lawyer concluded that "the evidence suggests that the only credible explanation is in one way or another the Russian state is involved in Litvinenko's murder".{{cite web|title = Litvinenko inquiry: Russia involved in spy's death, Scotland Yard says|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/30/litvinenko-inquiry-russia-involved-spy-death-scotland-yard|work = [[The Guardian]]|date=30 July 2015|accessdate = 3 August 2015|first = Jamie|last = Grierson}} ===Death and last statement=== Before his death, Litvinenko said: "You may succeed in silencing one man but the howl of protest from around the world, Mr. Putin, will reverberate in your ears for the rest of your life."{{cite web|title = Litvinenko Inquiry: David Cameron considers new sanctions against Russia after 'state-sponsored murder' of KGB spy in London|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/12111812/Alexander-Litvinenko-Inquiry-murdered-Russian-spy-live.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 22 January 2016}} On 22 November 2006, Litvinenko's medical staff at [[University College Hospital]] reported Litvinenko had suffered a "major setback" due to either heart failure or an overnight heart attack. He died on 23 November. The following day, Putin publicly stated: “Mr Litvinenko is, unfortunately, not Lazarus”. [[Scotland Yard]] stated that inquiries into the circumstances of how Litvinenko became ill would continue.{{cite news|title=Poisoned Russian former spy dies |publisher=CNN |date=23 November 2006 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/11/23/uk.spypoisoned/index.html |accessdate=23 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061124044529/http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/11/23/uk.spypoisoned/index.html |archivedate=24 November 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 24 November 2006, a posthumous statement was released, in which Litvinenko named Putin as the man behind his poisoning.
